speaker: JOE CRANDELL
line: What are you doing to Barnett?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: Excuse me?

speaker: JOE CRANDELL
line: What are you doing to Johnny?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: Go on back to your ward. There's nothing you can do for your friend now.

speaker: JOE CRANDELL
line: What?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: John Barnett is dead.

speaker: JOE CRANDELL
line: No, I heard him screaming.

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: I said John Barnett is dead. You understand? Go on, Crandell, get out of here. There's nothing more to see here. You understand?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I still don't get it. What does this have to do with us?

speaker: MULDER
line: Robbing a jewelry store is a federal crime.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know. I got a call from some guy I used to work with over at the violent crimes section, said it was important.

speaker: MULDER
line: Reggie! Reggie!

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Mulder, God, I hate it when you do that.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is Special Agent Scully. Reggie Purdue.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: How are you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened here?

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Lone gunman took out a salesgirl after she filled up a bag for him.

speaker: MULDER
line: You guys turn up anything?

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Not much... except... this. It's going to blow your mind.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why?

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: I'm telling you, Mulder, this is going to blow... your... mind.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What is it?

speaker: MULDER
line: Wait, wait a second...

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: You see why I called you?

speaker: MULDER
line: What about witness descriptions?

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: White male, five-eleven to six feet, ski mask.

speaker: MULDER
line: Damn it, Reggie, that's Barnett.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Yeah, but it can't be.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who's Barnett?

speaker: MULDER
line: It was my first case at the bureau. Barnett was doing armed jobs all over D.C. and getting away with it, very trigger-happy. Killed seven people. There was this big task force, Reggie was my ASAC. I was twenty-eight years old, right out of the academy. I had this theory on the case. Reggie thought I was full of it. I was full of it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What was the theory?

speaker: MULDER
line: That Barnett had an inside connection. An employee at the armored car company was tipping him off about large shipments of cash. Turns out I was sort of right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sort of?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, we planted bogus waybills, manifests with the armored car company to try to set a trap but Barnett was way ahead of us. That's... when the notes started.

speaker: SCULLY
line: "Fox can't guard the chicken coop."

speaker: MULDER
line: Clever, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: So you never caught him?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, we did. We did, but not, uh, not clean. An agent died because I screwed up.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And what happened to Barnett?

speaker: MULDER
line: He avoided the death penalty on a technicality. But he went down for every job he did. Consecutive terms, three-hundred-and-forty years. The judge promised me he would die in prison.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So you think he escaped?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, that's just it. He did die in prison, four years ago.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're sure?

speaker: MULDER
line: I was paying attention.

speaker: HENDERSON
line: This guy a friend of yours?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, I play golf with him every Sunday. What do you think?

speaker: HENDERSON
line: You just brought this in ten minutes ago.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're slipping, Henderson.

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Ten minutes may be enough time for you, Mulder. Of course, I wouldn't know that from personal experience.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah... seriously, what do you think?

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Okay, first impressions... the ink is fresh, the note was written in the last forty-eight hours. Ballpoint, but you knew that. A right-hander. Let's see... written by someone sitting down, but now I'm just showing off.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, does it match Barnett?

speaker: HENDERSON
line: I'd say it's him.

speaker: MULDER
line: But you're not sure?

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Ninety-five percent. The writing's sloppy. Some of the ascenders and descenders are heavier.

speaker: MULDER
line: Could it have been traced over an old note of Barnett's?

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Could be, but it's a damn good job if it is.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks, Henderson, I owe you one.

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Promises, promises.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: There's Barnett. We staked-out an airport warehouse but everything went to hell when Barnett took the driver of the armored truck hostage.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where's Mulder?

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: There, coming around back. Barnett doesn't see him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's got a clear shot.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Yeah, he should've taken it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But he couldn't.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: No, no, not with a hostage so close.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Because it's not by the book.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: It would have saved one life, maybe two. Bastard Barnett just started blasting away.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, Mulder did shoot Barnett.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Twice, in the shoulder and hand but not before Barnett killed the driver and Agent Steve Wallenberg. Mulder never forgave himself for that. You should have heard his testimony at Barnett's trial.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Probably had a lot to do with the sentence the judge gave Barnett.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: I'll never forget Mulder coming down from the witness stand and Barnett turning and saying he'd get Mulder. To tell you the truth, I wish Mulder had killed Barnett right there in the warehouse.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What did Henderson come up with?

speaker: MULDER
line: Ninety-five percent sure it's Barnett's handwriting.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Federal Bureau of Prisons sent me a copy of his death certificate. "Name of deceased, Barnett, John Irvin. Cause of death, cardiac arrest. Date, September sixteenth, 1989."

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then it must be a very clever copycat.

speaker: MULDER
line: The note was written in the last forty-eight hours.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Pull any prints?

speaker: MULDER
line: No prints.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Barnett had a lot of time on his hands while he was in prison, maybe he planned it with someone on the outside.

speaker: MULDER
line: Revenge from the grave? That'd be a neat trick.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He planned to get you, didn't he? I was just down talking to Agent Purdue.

speaker: MULDER
line: And he showed you the videotape?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You did the right thing, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did I? Steve Wallenberg had a wife and two kids. One of his boys is an all-star on his football team now. If I had pulled the trigger two seconds earlier and Wallenberg would be here to see his kid play. Instead, I got some dead man robbing jewelry stores and sending me haikus.

speaker: COACH
line: Fire it in there! Yeah, that's better!

speaker: WOMAN
line: Very good! Way to go, Alex!

speaker: COACH
line: Hustle it up! Come on, guys, line it up. Let's go.

speaker: QUARTERBACK
line: Down! Set! Hut!

speaker: COACH
line: Go, go, go! You're the man, there it is!

speaker: WOMAN
line: Very good!

speaker: COACH
line: That was over the line, let's go! Okay, watch the ball.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll get you, you son of a bitch!

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Agent Mulder, and I think that somebody is messing with your head.

speaker: MULDER
line: Barnett said he'd get me, you were there.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: I don't care what Barnett said, he's dead, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Apparently not.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Aw, come on. Let me tell you something, there are a lot of guys who know that Barnett made the threat.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's Barnett, Reggie.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: How could you say that?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know, I just feel it.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: You know, all this talk about you, about "Spooky" Mulder, I never used to pay it much mind. I figured it was just talk about how paranoid you were and all.

speaker: MULDER
line: And now?

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Remember the day you walked into my office wet from Quantico? You pissed me off just looking at you but then I saw how your mind worked. How you were always three jumps ahead. It was scary, Mulder. Everybody said so.

speaker: MULDER
line: I've heard this story.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Yeah, well, maybe you ought to hear it again. You let a lot of people down here in the bureau. They had big plans for you. A lot of people are saying that "Spooky" Mulder has become an embarrassment, a liability.

speaker: MULDER
line: What? Are you saying that somebody from the bureau's behind this?

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Maybe, maybe not. It's always best to cover your ass in any event.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sorry. This was just faxed. This is a copy of John Barnett's last will and testament. No surviving relatives, left what little he had to another prisoner... a Joe Crandall... and instructions for his body to be cremated. His will was executed six months after his death and this document states that his ashes were spread along the bank of the Delaware River by an employee of the crematory used by the prison.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: It's like I said, I think somebody's messing with your head.

speaker: MULDER
line: Killing a sales clerk just to leave me a note? I'd say that's going a little out of your way.

speaker: MULDER
line: He's older now, he may have put on some weight.

speaker: COMPUTER TECHNICIAN
line: How much older?

speaker: MULDER
line: Five years. He could be wearing any kind of disguise.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: Take us back to the day in question. Was it your impression, Agent Mulder, that John Barnett took a kind of a perverse pleasure in his crimes? Didn't he send you notes to taunt you?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, I felt that he was, uh, daring us to catch him. That he killed his victims almost as if it were part of a game.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: Describe for the court if you would, Agent Mulder, what happened when you finally caught John Barnett.

speaker: MULDER
line: We had a customs warehouse at the airport staked out. Now, we knew that Barnett had someone working for the armored car transport tipping him off about large cash shipments but we never figured that he would actually be inside the vehicle when it arrived. That's how Barnett was able to take the driver of the vehicle hostage.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: In other words, John Barnett used his own accomplice as a hostage?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, ma'am.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: And then what happened?

speaker: MULDER
line: We surrounded Barnett. We ordered him to surrender his hostage and his weapon.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: And where were you at this time, Agent Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: I was right behind Barnett.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: With a clear shot at the suspect?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, ma'am.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: But you didn't fire. Why?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, it's against F.B.I. regulations to unnecessarily endanger the life of a hostage. And I thought that with no means of escape, Barnett would give up.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: But what happened instead?

speaker: MULDER
line: The suspect, uh, John Barnett, fired his weapon point-blank at the hostage and then he turned his gun on Steve Wallenberg... shot him in the face.

speaker: PROSECUTOR
line: Thank you, Agent Mulder. No further questions at this time.

speaker: MULDER
line: He gunned him down just for spite.

speaker: DEFENSE LAWYER
line: Your honor, we object...

speaker: JUDGE
line: Witness will step down.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is a man with a wife and two small children...

speaker: JUDGE
line: Please step down...

speaker: MULDER
line: ...and you, you shot him without hesitation, without conscience, without an ounce of humanity.

speaker: DEFENSE LAWYER
line: Your honor, do something.

speaker: MULDER
line: Which is why you should die like an animal, you son of a bitch!

speaker: JUDGE
line: Agent Mulder, if you do not stop, I will find you in contempt of court. Order, order in the court. If there is not order in this court, I will be forced to clear the courtroom.

speaker: DEFENSE LAWYER
line: Your honor, the defense finds they are highly irregular and inflammatory against the defendant now and we ask that they be stricken from the record.

speaker: JUDGE
line: Duly noted, counsel. The jury will disregard the witness' last...

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: I'll... get... you.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll need printouts of every variation.

speaker: COMPUTER SPECIALIST
line: Right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I just got off the phone with the prison.

speaker: MULDER
line: What did they come up with?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, I called them on a hunch. John Barnett died of a heart attack, right? At least that's what it says on his death certificate. Well, I had them fax me all of his medical records. Barnett was admitted to the prison infirmary for an infection in his right hand. There isn't any indication or diagnosis of coronary complications. In fact, on his physical six months earlier, he was given a clean bill of health.

speaker: INMATE
line: Crandall. Someone to see you.

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: I don't get many visitors.

speaker: MULDER
line: You knew John Barnett?

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: Yes, sir.

speaker: MULDER
line: How well did you know him?

speaker: GUARD
line: Excuse me, ma'am.

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: Pretty well.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He left you everything he had in his will. You must've known him better than pretty well.

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: Used to change his bandages, and we just got to... know each other.

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you aware that Barnett died of cardiac arrest in this facility in 1989?

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: Cardiac arrest? Where does it say that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: On his death certificate.

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: He ain't dead, is he?

speaker: MULDER
line: Why do you say that?

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: Last time I saw John Barnett, it was right in that room over there. Doctor working on him with a knife took his bad hand clean off.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What doctor?

speaker: MULDER
line: Was it Doctor Ridley?

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: Yeah, yeah, it was Doctor Ridley, that's the one. He told me Johnny was dead but, uh, I knew it was a lie. Put a knife right up under my chin just for asking.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How could you tell Barnett wasn't dead?

speaker: JOE CRANDALL
line: I saw him looking at me. I saw him blink. Man, I'll never forget those eyes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you going to do?

speaker: MULDER
line: I know what I'm not going to do. I'm not going to hang around and wait for Barnett to send me another valentine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You mean the ghost of John Barnett.

speaker: MULDER
line: I didn't know you believe in ghosts, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hello? Yeah, just a minute. It's for you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Fox Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Barnett?

speaker: SCULLY
line: All right, all right...

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: You sound surprised.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, you know, shouldn't I be?

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: You know, it's illegal to tape another's phone call......without their express permission. Isn't that what they call it?

speaker: MULDER
line: In some states. What makes you think I'm taping you?

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Same thing makes me think you're putting a trace on this call.

speaker: MULDER
line: What state are you in?

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: The same state you are. I stood next to you in line for coffee this morning.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't think so.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Man, I'm everywhere you are. Everywhere. I own you.

speaker: MULDER
line: How do I know it's really you, Barnett?

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: What did I say to you in the courtroom? Did you ever... doubt me?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know, what did you tell me in the courtroom?

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Huh... if you think you're going to keep me on this phone with this clumsy act...

speaker: MULDER
line: Listen, by all accounts, John Barnett is a dead man.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Oh, you're the dead man... Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Fine. I just need confirmation that you are who you say you are.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: You want confirmation? You got it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Barnett? You there?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You lost him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, he was hip to the trace.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Was it Barnett?

speaker: MULDER
line: John Barnett was from New Hampshire. He had a slight accent. Listen to this.

speaker: MULDER ON RECORDER
line: I just need confirmation that you are who you say you are.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT ON RECORDER
line: You want confirmation? You got it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What did he mean by that?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know, but that is... John Barnett. I'm sure of it.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Oh... Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Reggie, it's Mulder.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Mulder, what do you want? It's the middle of the night.

speaker: MULDER
line: IT'S ONLY 10:45, old man.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Yeah, well... I was sleeping.

speaker: MULDER
line: Listen, Reggie, it doesn't look like Barnett's dead after all.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Now what?

speaker: MULDER
line: I got an inmate at the prison who swears he saw Barnett alive the night they say he died.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Mulder, go home. Get some rest.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, listen, Reggie, there's just one thing that doesn't make sense to me.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Yeah, what's that?

speaker: MULDER
line: That Agent Henderson said that that note that was left at the jewelry store was written by a right-hander.

speaker: REGGIE PURDUE
line: Yeah, so?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, this inmate at the prison swears he saw Barnett's right hand amputated. Reggie, you there? Hey, Reggie! Reggie! Reggie, what's going on? Are you there? What the hell is going on, Reggie? Reggie! What happened? Hey, Reggie! What's going on? Are you there? What the hell's going on, Reggie?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I hope you guys brought your fine-toothed comb. I want every piece of lint collected and analyzed. If nothing turns up, run it through it again. Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: His wife died of cancer six years ago. Never liked to talk about it. As long as I knew him, he was working on a mystery novel. He promised to show it to me once, but he never did. I think he was afraid I wouldn't like it. I'm probably the only guy on the bureau he trusted enough to even ask.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm sorry.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm just thinking how different things would've been if I would've taken that shot at Barnett when I had it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... we're still not a hundred percent sure that this is him.

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Fresh ink, slightly smeared... I hate to tell you, and I'm not known to be wrong about these things, but this note was most certainly written by a right-handed person. You see the pressure points inside the pen grooves? It's a dead giveaway.

speaker: MULDER
line: Would you be able to tell if this note was written by somebody using a prosthetic hand?

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Well, this fellow... and I'm assuming from the cursive figures here that it is a male suspect... he has a fairly nice, fluid style. Judging from the pressure variations in the connectors, this person would need good finger dexterity. You're not going to get that with a prosthesis.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you think it's the same person that wrote the first note.

speaker: HENDERSON
line: Uh-huh. This the guy you think killed Agent Purdue?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: HENDERSON
line: You know what occured to me? You never got any prints off those notes. If this guy was wearing a glove on his pen hand, the note wouldn't be smeared like it is. For what it's worth.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I was just trying to find you. Listen to this. According to the A.M.A., Doctor Ridley, who signed Barnett's death certificate, hasn't officially been a doctor since 1979.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean?

speaker: SCULLY
line: His membership expired and wasn't renowed after the state of Maryland revoked his medical license for flagrant research malpractice and misuse of a government grant.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where does it say that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Right here. In the federal journal for the National Institute of Health.

speaker: MULDER
line: What kind of research?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He was conducting experiments on young children afflicted with a disease called progeria.

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: The patient you see is an eight-year-old girl suffering from the advanced stages of progeria.

speaker: MULDER
line: She looks about ninety.

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: Only about a hundred cases have ever been reported so the disease is rare.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But fatal.

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: Some progeria patients make it to early adulthood but others become terminal at age seven or eight.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's the cause of death?

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: Clinically, it's cardiac or cerebral vascular disease but actually, these poor kids die of old age.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that Doctor Ridley?

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: Yes, in 1974. Joe Ridley thought that he could take their accelerated aging and slow it down. Initially, some of his lab work was promising but then... things got out of control. He wanted to begin human trials.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why wasn't he allowed to?

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: Because he hadn't met the criteria. It was all too hypothetical, too... dangerous. I mean... I knew Joe Ridley. He didn't care about those kids. He talked about them as if they were laboratory animals. This terrible disease, progeria... he saw it as "a wonderful opportunity." He used those exact words with me once. An opportunity to "unlock all the secrets." When they refused to allow the human trials, he became enraged. Do you know what they called Joe Ridley behind his back?

speaker: MULDER
line: What?

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: Doktor Mengele.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, how did Doctor Ridley eventually lose his medical license?

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: He went ahead with the human trials secretly on an out-patient basis. When we learned about it, of course, we terminated his grant and filed charges with the state medical boards.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm afraid your colleague, Doctor Ridley, has dropped off the face of the earth.

speaker: NIH DOCTOR
line: Yeah. Although, it's rumored he went to South America to continue his work.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You just don't reverse aging.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ridley's found a way.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Listen to what you're saying.

speaker: MULDER
line: He wanted human research subjects, right? Prisoners. Prisoners like John Barnett.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it's science fiction.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, what would you have said twenty years ago about gene splicing, DNA fingerprinting, cloning, artificial intelligence? Maybe we're not looking for a man in his late forty's after all. Maybe John Barnett has found the perfect disguise... youth.

speaker: MULDER
line: I want to age him backwards now. Let's start with ten years. Now, five years more. And add twenty pounds. A healthy twenty pounds.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ridley's notes from the human trials at N.I.H. indicate he didn't see aging as inevitable but as an opportunistic disease. A disease that could be prevented, reversed even, by changing the chemical cues that trigger certain genes. However, there is no evidence whatsoever that Ridley's work yielded any results or that his theories, all hope to the contrary, hold any validity. According to the leading scientific journals, projections on this kind of genetic engineering are at best speculative and futuristic.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who is it?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: Doctor Joe Ridley.

speaker: MULDER
line: If you're really Doctor Joseph Ridley, where've you been for the past five years?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: I originally continued my research in Mexico but for the last three years, I spent my time in Central America. In Belize, to be exact.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about Barnett?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: John Barnett is the only patient left. The only one who survived the experiments.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about you?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: My appearance is decieving. I have no more than a month to live as I am dying from a rare cerebral vascular disease.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The same disease that kills the kids suffering from progeria?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: That's right. An unfortunate side effect of the treatment. By using the genetic components of progeria, I was able to reverse the aging process in much the same way the disease expedited it. At the same time, I and my patients became genetically susceptible to the same ailments a child six or eight would if he had the disease.

speaker: MULDER
line: And what about Barnett?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: John Barnett. If I didn't so personally detest the man, I might call him my one triumph.

speaker: MULDER
line: Barnett's not dying.

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: Only his eyes, which for some reason do not respond to the gene therapy. Otherwise, John Barnett appears to be thriving.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But how?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: I varied Barnett's treatment. Once I isolated the progeria receptors, I stumbled onto something quite unexpected... these same genes related to the production of myelin.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The material that insulates neurons in the body.

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: Yes. You see, myelin is not present in the very young and by reversing the effects of aging, I found, with Barnett, I was able to regulate the production of myelin. Myelin being the material that prohibits you or I from, say, regenerating a new hand if we were to have ours cut off.

speaker: MULDER
line: You were able to grow John Barnett a new hand?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: Not exactly. Not a human hand, anyway. I could never get the cells to divide or behave properly.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I, I'm afraid to ask. What kind of hand did you grow?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: There had been some successful work done in London. By taking samples of what we call cell morphegins from an amputated salamander arm and applying them to the back of the creature, they were able to grow a new limb on a completely different part of the body. But only on salamanders.

speaker: MULDER
line: Until John Barnett.

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Unbelievable.

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: My work has cost me dearly. I'm an outcast in the medical community. I was called Doctor Mengele, Doctor Frankenstein but I didn't care.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Because you knew that if your theories panned out...

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: The man who owns the fountain of youth controls the world. When the A.M.A. censured me, certain sponsors came out of the woodwork. One of them is the U.S. government.

speaker: MULDER
line: They financed your research?

speaker: JOSEPH RIDLEY
line: You might be more surprised to learn just how high up the ladder this dirty little secret goes.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: I know why you've contacted me. Listen and I'll explain. I am not particularly proud of the way in which this matter was handled but, uh, like it or not, John Barnett is a fact of life.

speaker: MULDER
line: I wish Agent Perdue were around to appreciate the irony.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: The government knew full well that Barnett was in the country. You, of course, know that Barnett stole all of Ridley's research.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, Ridley was...

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: Well, what Ridley doesn't know is that our government is bargaining with Barnett to buy it from him.

speaker: MULDER
line: What does he want?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: A lot of money, immunity, safe haven.

speaker: MULDER
line: Will he get it?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: He holds all the cards.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're aware that this... freak of science you're negotiating with is a murderer?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: The information he has... could change the course of mankind. Consider the options.

speaker: MULDER
line: I will.

speaker: SCULLY ON MACHINE
line: Hi. This is Dana Scully. Please leave a message after the tone.

speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
line: Reading messages.

speaker: MARGARET SCULLY ON MACHINE
line: Hi, Dana, it's Mom. I just wanted to call and say hi. Um, give me a call, whenever. Okay, bye.

speaker: KATHY ON MACHINE
line: Hi, Dana, it's Kathy. Look, I hope you're still going to meet me before my cello recital...

speaker: MULDER
line: What's that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's my private answering machine. Or at least it used to be.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean?

speaker: SCULLY
line: When I ran from the shower this morning, I heard someone dialing in my private code and replaying my messages. Last night, before Doctor Ridley, I could have sworn that someone was in my apartment. But when Ridley knocked, I thought I'd mistaken the noise for him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: This morning, I took this down to prints before I came here. John Barnett's left index oblique is on the underside of this unit.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder. Barnett?

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Your new friend, Ridley? Don't grow to fond of him... huh? He's going to die soon like the rest of your friends.

speaker: MULDER
line: The rest of my friends?

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: One by one.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're not that smart.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Tell me, you're not going to make me prove it to you again, are you? Oh, well, no matter. It'll be your turn soon enough.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, you won't get that chance.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Oh, no? Who's going to stop me, huh? Man, this is... this is the land of the free! Well, I'm just checking in. Bye. For now.

speaker: MULDER
line: What does Barnett know about your phone messages?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, that my mother called for no reason and I'm meeting a friend before her cello recital.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where's that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Before the performance and during, we're working at a disadvantage because we don't know exactly what Barnett looks like. Study each of these faces. Know them, particularly the eyes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm including a diagram of the theater. You have six front entrances and four more backstage.

speaker: MULDER
line: We know that if he shows, he'll be keying on Scully. So wherever she is, she should not leave your sight. We've got two hours before the performance. Know this place inside and out. We don't want any shots fired if we can help it. We want to take Barnett alive, okay? How are you feeling?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's the first time I've ever played the target.

speaker: MULDER
line: Let's make sure it's not the last time.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Gun!

speaker: MULDER
line: Down! Check her out!

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Stay back, Mulder! Shut up...

speaker: MULDER
line: Back off, back off...

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: I'll kill her! Don't even think about it!

speaker: MULDER
line: Just let her go.

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Go ahead and shoot. Go ahead, man. Shoot, Mulder! What are you afraid of, huh? What, it's against regulations... huh? No, man. You need me alive, don't you? Because I'm the only one who knows where the research is! Huh? So I could shoot her! And you just to live with it, don't you, huh?

speaker: MULDER
line: Shut up!

speaker: KATHY
line: Please, no. Please, please, please...

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: How about it, Mulder?

speaker: KATHY
line: Please, please, please, please, please...

speaker: JOHN BARNETT
line: Just like old times, huh? Huh?

speaker: MULDER
line: Call an ambulance!

speaker: AGENT
line: Okay... it's okay, Scully, an ambulance is on the way. You all right? Don't try to move...

speaker: MAN-IN-BLACK
line: Where are they? Can you here me?

speaker: DOCTOR
line: One, two, three...

speaker: MAN-IN-BLACK
line: Where'd you hide them?

speaker: MULDER
line: How you feeling?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Like somebody kicked me in the ribs.

speaker: MULDER
line: That bullet went through eight layers of kevlar, you're lucky to be alive.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about him?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, they flew in three specialists to try to save his life. That guy in the ugly suit there is probably C.I.A. Been trying to talk to him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is Barnett conscious?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but he's not talking.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I know what you did wasn't by the book.

speaker: MULDER
line: Tells you a lot about the book, doesn't it?

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Barnett! Barnett, come on!

speaker: MAN
line: Vitals dropping...

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Barnett... shock him, now!

speaker: SCULLY
line: They lost him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Bastard will take that research with him to the grave.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where do you think it is?

speaker: MULDER
line: Who knows? If Barnett didn't destroy it, he could have stashed it anywhere. Which would have a cruel irony, wouldn't it? Scientific knowledge that could change the course of mankind buried out in a field somewhere or in some safe deposit box. Getting old, just like the rest of us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: If it didn't destroy it, chances are that somehow, someday, somebody will find it.

speaker: MULDER
line: And when they do... maybe he can get his revenge from beyond the grave but somehow, I feel like we haven't heard the last from John Barnett.
